problem: Find all real numbers $x$ satisfying \[\frac{2x-5}{x+3} \ge 2.\](Give your answer in interval notation.)
solution:
Subtracting $2$ from both sides, we get
\begin{align*}
 \frac{2x-5}{x+3} - 2 &\ge 0 \\
 \frac{2x-5 - 2(x+3)}{x+3} &\geq 0 \\
 \frac{-11}{x+3} &\ge 0.
\end{align*}Therefore, we must have $x+3 < 0,$ so $x < -3.$ Therefore, the solution set is $\boxed{ (-\infty, -3) }.$
gptanswer: We begin by subtracting 2 from both sides of the inequality to get \[\frac{2x-5}{x+3} - 2 \ge 0.\]Simplifying the left-hand side gives \[\frac{2x-5-2x-6}{x+3} = \frac{-11}{x+3}.\]Thus we want to solve \[\frac{-11}{x+3} \ge 0.\]The only way this can be true is if $x+3$ is negative, so we want $x+3<0$, or $x<-3$. Therefore, the solution to the inequality is $\boxed{(-\infty,-3)}$.
